Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 53344-001  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance Cluster (C-KSTA) 
November 2019 
 
 
 
 
Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021–2023 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  DOC  –  Department of Communications 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
  EROD-SDI  –  Statistics and Data Innovation Unit, Office of the Chief 
Economist and Director General 
  GVC  –  global value chain 
  IT  –  information technology 
  KIDB  –  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific database 
  SCB  –  statistical capacity building 
  SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars.

Development

Department (ERCD)

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Since 1969 the Asian Development Bank (ADB), through the Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD), has been producing its annual flagship statistical 
publication—Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific—with the 2019 edition released in September 
being the 50th edition. Throughout these 50 years, the publication has compiled and presented 
official statistics for ADB regional members. The featured indicators have continued to evolve to 
take  into  account  developments  over  time,  e.g.,  in  terms  of  development  goals,  from  the 
Millennium Development Goals that started in 2000 up to the current Sustainable Development 
Goals (SDGs). The coverage of statistics presented in Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific has 
also expanded over time, from the very basic key indicators in its first edition in 1969 to a more 
comprehensive set of statistics now. This has allowed it to maintain its relevance to data users, 
which include ADB Management and staff. Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific has been one 
of the most downloaded knowledge products of ADB.1 The proposed knowledge and support 
technical assistance (TA) will support the preparation of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
through research and development in ADB, enabling the continuous provision of the latest 
comprehensive  compendium  and  analysis  of  trends  in  economic,  social,  financial,  and 
environmental indicators (including the SDG indicators) of ADB’s regional members. Aside from 
providing  the  latest  comprehensive  compendium  and  analysis  of  trends  for  ADB  regional 
members, it is intended that Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific will provide a unique set of 
indicators on global value chains (GVCs) that capture trade links across countries and industries 
while accounting for the complex input–output relationships involved in producing goods and 
services.  Annual  special  supplements  that  provide  analysis  on  an  important  data-  and 
methodology-related issue, including those resulting from ADB’s statistical capacity building 
(SCB) initiatives, will also be prepared. In addition to the main publication, Key Indicators for Asia 
and the Pacific will continue to be accessible in a digital format through the new Key Indicators 
for Asia and the Pacific database (KIDB),2 and will continue to evolve as a data product that 
provides users easy access and interaction with data. 
 
2.  The knowledge and support TA cluster is included in the approved 2019 work plan of 
ERCD and is an endorsed corporate priority TA project. The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2030,3 which envisages ADB’s role as a knowledge institution in Asia and the Pacific, expanding 
knowledge partnerships and knowledge dissemination.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Statistics are used by governments for designing policies and for making decisions 
concerning the economy and society, as well as by private individuals for evaluating business 
prospects, e.g., by looking at some sets of statistics, or by researchers like think tanks and 
academia in the analysis of the development issues impacting an economy and factors affecting 
development. The need to uphold the classic data quality standards of accuracy, reliability, and 
timeliness is always a priority concern for producers and users of statistics. This implies that, for 
 
1  Download statistics of ADB’s Department of Communications for January–June 2019 show 13,234 downloads for 
Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2018 from the entire ADB catalogue. The total number of downloads is a proxy 
indicator that can provide a picture on how useful Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific data are to users. Ideally, 
the total number of downloads is complemented by the count of downloads from developing member economies as 
well as the count of KI data being cited or used in policy papers, research, and news articles. Coming up on more 
granular download statistics will be coordinated with DOC.   
2  https://kidb.adb.org/kidb/ 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
4  The TA cluster first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 October 2019.

2 
policymakers  and  development  planners to  be  able  to make sound decisions,  high-quality 
statistics—i.e., accurate, reliable, and timely—are desired. 
 
4.  Among the data standards, dissemination is also considered an important aspect because 
good statistics, if not effectively disseminated, defeat the purpose for which they are generated 
and, therefore, are rendered not useful to the intended audience or users. Current expectations 
are that accurate, reliable, and timely statistics are made available and are accessible in different 
media, going beyond the printed form. Experience with past Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
editions indicate the need to strengthen collaboration with the Department of Communications 
(DOC) on disseminating Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific through DOC channels. 
 
5.  While Asia and the Pacific has attained significant economic growth, the recognition that 
growth could be more inclusive persists, which is consistent with the aim of the SDGs of leaving 
no one behind. High-quality data with greater granularization are desirable for the design of 
policies that promote the welfare of the disadvantaged sectors of society. Evidence-based policies 
rely on access to high-quality statistics for informing inter- and intra-country analyses on a wide 
variety of topics, including the SDGs and GVCs. The statistical capacity of ADB developing 
member countries (DMCs) also needs to be strengthened and updated for the production of high-
quality statistics, a continuous process that will help create awareness among members as 
producers of data as well as among users of data. In this sense, the cluster TA will build on the 
achievements and lessons learned from the Key Indicators 2018-2020 cluster TA5 and previous 
Key Indicators TAs, where standards followed in compiling critical macroeconomic data (e.g., 
national accounts, balance of payments, government finance statistics) for policymaking were 
revisited and revised toward adopting latest international standards. By doing this and subject to 
capacity of DMCs, the TA will enable a harmonized data set for the DMCs that meet international 
standards, thereby fostering regional cooperation and integration. ADB has also implemented 
various SCB TA grants that have resulted in improvements in DMCs’ statistical capacity, e.g., TAs 
that aimed to develop the capacity of national statistical systems that benefited countries such as 
Bhutan, Cambodia, and Myanmar; TAs that explored ways of improving data collection; and 
projects that improved the quality of statistics collected. 
  
6.  Moreover, as an international organization, ADB needs to have a strong information 
base—a  one-stop  database  that  is  of  high  quality  and  attuned  to  the  latest  international 
compilation standards—on its members’ socioeconomic, financial, and environmental status for 
tracking progress in Asia and the Pacific and to support its operations in implementing Strategy 
2030. 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
7.  As Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific involves recurring data and research work that 
are often closely linked across editions, the TA cluster modality will be used. The TA also needs 
a multiyear implementation period with broadly defined scope, allowing advanced preparation and 
flexibility for refining each subproject as needed. 
 
 
5 ADB. Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2018-2020. https://www.adb.org/projects/50160-007/main.

3 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
8.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impacts: evidence-based policy-making, 
investment decisions, and project design influenced in ADB DMCs.6 The TA cluster will have the 
following outcome: use of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific data and analysis for evidence-
based policy-making by DMC officials and economic researchers sustained.7 
 
9.  Output 1: Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific and other statistical publications 
prepared and published. The TA will support the production of the 2021, 2022, and 2023 editions 
of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific that will entail annual data collection activities from 
national, international, and ADB sources to compile updated statistical tables and the KIDB on 
regional member countries. With the emergence of new development issues and the changing 
needs of Asia and the Pacific, data provided by Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific on ADB 
regional members become crucial to evidence-based policymaking. As such, the publication is 
intended to serve as a resource for information related to the development issues confronting 
ADB  regional  members.  It  presents  a  comprehensive  set  of  economic,  financial,  social, 
environmental, and selected statistical indicators of the SDGs through its country tables, regional 
tables  in  eight  broad  themes  (people;  economy  and  output;  money,  finance,  and  prices; 
globalization; transport and communication; energy and electricity; environment; and government 
and governance), and the SDG tables by goal. It also covers the GVC statistics that have been 
included in Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific since the 2015 edition. GVC statistics show 
how the economies in Asia and the Pacific continue to strengthen, broaden, and diversify their 
participation in global production networks. Other innovative work will include improvements in 
statistical databases and data collection from ADB’s DMCs, such as the use of the Structured 
Data and Metadata eXchange.8 The Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific publication and the 
data in it will be disseminated digitally in coordination with the DOC via the ADB website and the 
new KIDB (footnote 2). Its impact will be monitored through new parameters, aside from the usual 
download metrics, that consider the new ways of disseminating information, e.g., through social 
media platforms. As it is also intended as a reference for ADB Management and operations, 
dissemination of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific will also cater to internal clients to create 
awareness on available statistical information on ADB DMCs by holding knowledge-sharing 
events. Moreover, while digital publication will be the main form of dissemination, a limited number 
of printed copies (around 400) will be produced for promotional or awareness-raising purposes 
and to meet requests of some specific groups for Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific data. 
 
10.  The TA will also support the production of another data product with high demand among 
data users—the annual Basic Statistics brochure—specifically the 2021, 2022, and 2023 editions. 
Like Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, Basic Statistics has been a long-existing data product 
of ADB, having first been published in 1998. Basic Statistics presents current data for ADB DMCs 
on core and selected economic, environmental, and social indicators used globally to track 
progress toward the SDGs. It is intended to serve as a handy and comprehensive source of 
snapshot information on ADB’s DMCs. As in the past editions, Basic Statistics for 2021, 2022, 
and 2023 will be available digitally on the ADB website and will also be accessible using mobile 
technology.  A  limited  number  of  printed  copies  will  be  produced  for  internal  use  of  ADB 
 
6  Defined by the TA. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
8  Structured Data and Metadata eXchange refers to an international standard of data and metadata exchange. Data 
reported according to this standard allows multipurpose sharing for national data exchange as well as sharing with 
international organizations.

4 
Management and staff and for consumption of the general public. Basic Statistics is also used by 
ADB for awareness-raising events, which help promote the profile of ADB as a knowledge center 
in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
11.  Output 2: Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific special supplements prepared and 
published. The TA will support the preparation of the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
special supplements for 2021, 2022, and 2023. Candidate topics for the special supplement will 
generally draw from the experiences and results of ADB SCB projects, or topics on statistical 
measurement, methodology, and applications of statistical standards. It has been noted that, 
through the data collection activities of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific from official 
statistical partners in the ADB DMCs, the statistical capacity of DMCs can be indirectly gauged. 
Data collected provide information on the concepts used for the compilation, the degree of 
compliance with international standards, data collection practices, data limitations, dissemination 
avenues, and areas for improvement. For national accounts, for example, some DMCs are still 
not completely adherent to the recommendations of the 2008 System of National Accounts9 and 
need technical support to improve the compilation of their national accounts. Enhancing the 
capacity of national statistical offices in compiling national accounts is one of the outputs identified 
in ongoing SCB projects, along with ways of using innovative data sources, e.g., satellite images, 
mobile data, or social media data to produce disaggregated data for official statistics, or on 
developing  a  suite  of  innovative  socioeconomic  data  compilation  and  analysis  frameworks 
comprising extended supply and use tables, extended input–output tables, and social accounting 
matrixes. All these examples provide information on what areas SCB projects can focus on in 
future and can be candidate topics for the special supplement. 
 
12.  Output 3: Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific database updated regularly and 
ADB Statistics Portal and AsiaData application upgraded. With the release of the new user-
friendly KIDB in September 2019, accessing information on ADB’s regional members is more 
convenient and interactive. The database’s advanced functionality allows users to experience 
improved data searching, flexibility in downloading data, and customized data visualization. The 
challenge is sustaining the continuous modernization and innovation of the database for it to 
continue to be a reliable one-stop source of information on ADB’s regional members. The TA will 
support the continuous improvement of the database to keep up with the demands of users and 
with changes in technology. 
 
13.  The TA will support the maintenance and regular updating of the Portal for Statistics 
Resources, or the Statistics Portal.10 The portal offers a systematic structure for organizing and 
disseminating the in-house statistics resources in ADB, e.g., databases and survey data sets. It 
provides data support and information regarding data availability and resources that are useful 
for research activities of ADB or for formulating policy recommendations. It provides information 
on how to access or procure statistics resources that are not available within ADB or that cannot 
be obtained through the internet. The portal is available internally within ADB. 
 
14.  Upgrading the AsiaData application—a visualization tool for mobile devices that presents 
the  latest  macroeconomic  and  social  indicators  for  ADB's  regional  members—will  also  be 
supported by the TA. The application allows users free access to the data and allows them to 
easily construct their own graphs and tables using any of the over 200 featured indicators for ADB 
regional members. Users can readily compare countries for one indicator or compare trends of 
one indicator for a country. Similar to ready-made graphs, user-defined graphs can be saved or 
 
9  The United Nations. 2010. System of National Accounts 2008. New York. https://doi.org/10.18356/4fa11624-en.  
10  https://statistics.adb.org/statresource/

5 
shared, and corresponding data tables can also be shown. The application is available for Android 
and Apple operating systems. Upgrading the application will require information technology (IT) 
expertise. 
 
15.  Output 4: Workshops for knowledge sharing and dissemination conducted. Among 
the data standards, dissemination is also considered an important aspect. Current expectations 
are that accurate, reliable, and timely statistics are made available and are accessible in different 
media, going beyond the printed form. Under the TA, the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
publication and data will be disseminated via web launch and/or launch events.11 It will include 
key results and data stories about Asia and the Pacific that are based on the data included in Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific. Knowledge-sharing sessions within ADB will also be conducted 
for the special supplement and the GVCs, on Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific as a data 
product to increase awareness about the publication and the KIDB, on the Statistics Portal, and 
on AsiaData. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $2,400,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF Others). Detailed cost estimates 
and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA subproject proposal submitted for 
approval. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA cluster through the Statistics and Data Innovation Unit of the 
Office of the Chief Economist and Director General (EROD-SDI) (Table 1). EROD-SDI will 
coordinate with other ADB units (regional and other departments, resident missions, and sector 
and thematic groups) and statistical partners in ADB regional members in undertaking the TA 
activities.  The  cluster  TA  will  be  implemented  over  52  months—from  September  2020  to 
December  2024.  Each  TA  subproject  proposal  will  be  submitted  for  approval  to  the  chief 
economist and director general of ERCD, in accordance with the business process for knowledge 
and support TA cluster processing. Subproject activities will start only after approval.

18.  Subprojects. The TA cluster will be implemented through three subprojects (Appendix 2). 
Each subproject will be designed to support the achievement of the cluster outputs (paras. 9–15) 
when needed during the implementation period (Table 2).12 
 
Table 2: Indicative Implementation Period and Budget Allocation for Subprojects 
Budget  
Item  Subproject Title  Implementation Period  ($’000) 
Subproject 1  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021  September 2020–June 2022   800

Subproject 3  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023  October 2022–December 2024  800 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
19.  Consulting  services.  Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  through  the  individual 
consultant selection process to provide international and national consulting inputs. A firm will 
also be recruited using quality- and cost-based selection with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio for the 
enhancement and maintenance of AsiaData. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with 
the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
20.  ADB’s procurement. Statistical and other software, survey data sets, and IT equipment 
will be procured under the TA as needed and in coordination with the Office of Information 
Systems  and  Technology  for  IT  hardware-related  procurement.  Detailed  implementation 
 
12 Detailed implementation arrangements, including consultant terms of reference, will be presented in each subproject 
report processed under the cluster.

7 
arrangements of ADB procurement will be finalized prior to approval of each TA subproject. 
Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy and the Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated staff instructions. Upon TA 
completion, assets procured will be turned over or disposed of following ADB guidelines and 
procedures. 
 
21.  Social media and websites. The contents of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific and 
related products will be prominently disseminated via the ADB website, dedicated Key Indicators 
for Asia and the Pacific landing page,13 and the KIDB as well as on social media in coordination 
with DOC. Since the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific landing page is part of the ADB 
website, its maintenance will be coordinated with DOC. EROD-SDI will be responsible for the 
maintenance of the KIDB. Dissemination of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific on social media 
will be through infographics and news releases on ADB’s official page and will also be coordinated 
with DOC. 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,400,000 on a grant basis for 
the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021–2023, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
13 https://www.adb.org/publications/series/key-indicators-for-asia-and-the-pacific

10  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Subproject 1 (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021: Target approval date – December 2019) 
1.1.  Engage consultants and commission background research for the special supplement (September 2020–
February 2021). 
1.2.  Conduct data collection and generation of statistical tables (March–May 2021). 
1.3.  Prepare and publish Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific special supplement (January–September 2021). 
1.4.  Continuously update ADB Statistics Portal and KIDB (March–September 2021). 
1.5.  Draft, review, and edit Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific contents (June–September 2021). 
1.6.  Finalize and disseminate publications (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific reports, Basic Statistics, working 
papers, blog posts, or journal papers and/or policy briefs) (April–December 2021). 
1.7.  Conduct dissemination workshops (May and September 2021). 
 
2.  Subproject 2 (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2022: Target approval date – October 2021) 
2.1.  Engage consultants and commission background research for the special supplement (January–March 2022). 
2.2.  Conduct data collection and generation of statistical tables (March–May 2022). 
2.3.  Prepare and publish Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific special supplement (January–September 2022). 
2.4.  Continuously update ADB statistics portal and KIDB (March–September 2022). 
2.5.  Draft, review, and edit Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific contents (June–September 2022). 
2.6.  Finalize and disseminate publications (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific reports, Basic Statistics, working 
papers, blog posts, or journal papers and/or policy briefs) (April–December 2022). 
2.7.  Conduct dissemination workshops (May and September 2022). 
 
3.  Subproject 3 (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023: Target approval date – October 2022) 
3.1.  Engage consultants and commission background research for the special supplement (January–March 2023). 
3.2.  Conduct data collection and generation of statistical tables (March–May 2023). 
3.3.  Prepare and publish Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific special supplement (January–September 2023). 
3.4.  Continuously update ADB Statistics Portal and KIDB (March–September 2023). 
3.5.  Draft, review, and edit Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific contents (June–September 2023). 
3.6.  Finalize and disseminate publications (Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific reports, Basic Statistics, working 
papers, blog posts, or journal papers and/or policy briefs) (April–December 2023). 
3.7.  Conduct dissemination workshops (May and September 2023). 
 
Technical Assistance Management Activities 
Hire consultants (September 2020–September 2023). 
Procure information technology equipment, required software, and data sets (schedule to be determined). 
Inputs 
ADB: $1,200,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) 
ADB: $1,200,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund - Other Sources (TASF Others) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DOC = Department of Communications, DMC = developing member country, EROD-
SDI = Statistics and Data Innovation Unit (Office of the Chief Economist and Director General, ERCD), KIDB = Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific database, TA = technical assistance, TASF = technical assistance special fund. 
a  Defined by TA. 
b  Downloads count PDF and EPub files hosted on ADB.org and outbound links from ADB.org to country tables and 
other files (Excel and PDF) hosted on the ADB Data Library. The same applies to the download counts of Basic 
Statistics and the KI Special Supplements. 
c   A visit is a series of actions that begins when a visitor views the first page from the ADB server and ends when the 
visitor leaves the site or remains idle beyond the idle-time limit. The default idle-time limit is thirty minutes. This time 
limit can be changed by the ADB system administrator. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Appendix 2  11 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 
Indicative outputs and activities  Subproject 1 of the TA cluster will cover the preparation of the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 main publication, the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 special supplement, and 
Basic Statistics 2021, and update of the KIDB, AsiaData, and 
Statistics Portal. 
 
Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 will cover the production 
of country tables for ADB’s 49 regional members, the status of Asia 
and the Pacific in meeting selected targets for the 17 Sustainable 
Development Goals, regional trends embodied in eight themes, and 
the GVC updates. This will entail collaboration with and data 
collection from official statistical partners in the regional members and 
international organizations. 
 
The subproject will support the continuous improvement and 
maintenance of the new KIDB. It will be updated based on the 
updates done for the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 
statistical tables, and its features further enhanced. The Statistics 
Portal—the repository of surveys, census, and other micro-level 
data—will be enhanced to capitalize on Microsoft SharePoint to 
facilitate easy access to data that can be used for socioeconomic 
research by ADB staff. AsiaData will be updated alongside the KIDB. 
 
For the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2021 special 
supplement, different topics will be considered based on results and 
progress of ongoing or completed SCB projects. These candidate 
topics will be presented to ERCD management before finalizing the 
topic for subproject 1 special supplement. A candidate topic can be 
on measuring the contribution of the digital economy to the total 
economy where background papers will be solicited from renowned 
economic writers and statisticians. GVC can also be a topic to 
present statistical analysis of the evolution of selected DMCs’ 
participation in GVCs. 
Indicative implementation  ADB will administer subproject 1. EROD-SDI will be directly 
arrangements  responsible for administering and supervising the subproject, 
engaging and managing consultants, procuring IT hardware and 
software, and producing outputs. 
Subproject 1 proposal will be submitted to the ERCD chief economist 
and director general for approval following the business process for 
knowledge and support TA cluster processing. 
Implementation schedule  September 2020–June 2022 
Subproject 2  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2022 
Indicative outputs and activities  Subproject 2 of the TA cluster will cover the preparation of the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2022 main publication, the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2022 special supplement, and 
Basic Statistics 2022. As with subproject 1, the KIDB will be updated 
based on the updates done for the Key Indicators for Asia and the 
Pacific 2022 statistical tables, and its features further enhanced as 
needed. The Statistics Portal will be continuously enhanced to ensure 
that users have easy access to micro data needed for socioeconomic 
research. AsiaData will be updated alongside the KIDB.

12  Appendix 2 
For the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2022 special 
supplement, different topics will be considered based on results and 
progress of ongoing or completed SCB projects. These candidate 
topics will be presented to ERCD management before finalizing the 
topic for the subproject 2 special supplement. One candidate topic 
can be on opportunities and challenges of using administrative data 
and other nontraditional sources for compiling labor statistics, a study 
that examines specific case studies of using these data sources to 
compile work and employment statistics based on new international 
standards of labor market statistics. GVC can also be a topic to 
present statistical analysis of the evolution of selected DMCs’ 
participation in GVCs. 
Indicative implementation  ADB will administer subproject 2. EROD-SDI will be directly 
arrangements  responsible for administering and supervising the subproject, 
engaging and managing consultants, procuring IT hardware and 
software, and producing outputs. 
Subproject 2 proposal will be submitted to the ERCD chief economist 
and director general for approval following the business process for 
knowledge and support TA cluster processing. 
Implementation schedule  October 2021–June 2023 
Subproject 3  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023 
Indicative outputs and activities  Subproject 3 of the TA cluster will cover the preparation of the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023 main publication, the Key 
Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023 special supplement, and 
Basic Statistics 2023. As with subprojects 1 and 2, the KIDB will be 
updated based on the updates done for the Key Indicators for Asia 
and the Pacific 2023 statistical tables, and its features further 
enhanced as needed. The Statistics Portal will be continuously 
enhanced to ensure that users have easy access to micro data 
needed for socioeconomic research. AsiaData will be updated 
alongside the KIDB. 
 
For the topic of Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2023 special 
supplement, ideas will be solicited within EROD-SDI in the context of 
ongoing or completed SCB projects and in consultation with ERCD 
management. GVC can be a topic to present statistical analysis of the 
evolution of selected DMCs’ participation in GVCs. The topics will be 
finalized in time for the submission of the subproject 3 proposal. 
Indicative implementation  ADB will administer subproject 3. EROD-SDI will be directly 
arrangements  responsible for administering and supervising the subproject, 
engaging and managing consultants, procuring IT hardware and 
software, and producing outputs. 
Subproject 3 proposal will be submitted to the ERCD chief economist 
and director general for approval following the business process for 
knowledge and support TA cluster processing. 
Implementation schedule  October 2022–December 2024 
ADB = Asian Development Bank; DMC = developing member country; ERCD = Economic Research and Regional 
Cooperation Department; EROD-SDI = Statistics and Data Innovation Unit, Office of the Chief Economist and Director 
General; GVC = global value chain; IT = information technology; KIDB = Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
database; SCB = statistical capacity building; TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Economist and Director General
